sections.headline: User-level requirements focusing on transparency and user control over personal data processing.

points.label: Transparency of collection and processing
points.text: Users must have visibility into how their data is collected and processed.

points.label: Consent and purpose limitation
points.text: Personal data handling must respect consent and purpose limitation.

points.label: Control and revocation
points.text: Users must retain control over data sharing and be able to revoke access/sharing.

sections.headline: Application-level requirements for secure data processing pipelines and protection against manipulation.

points.label: Secure processing pipeline
points.text: Applications must enforce secure data processing pipelines.

points.label: Encryption in transit and at rest
points.text: Sensitive data must be encrypted in transit and at rest (as implemented/used by the application).

points.label: Validation against manipulation
points.text: Data validation must prevent injection and manipulation attacks.

sections.headline: Platform-level requirements for isolation and side-channel resistant computation resources and mediated data exchange.

points.label: Tenant isolation
points.text: The platform must isolate workloads across tenants.

points.label: Side-channel resistance
points.text: Computational resources must prevent side-channel leakage.

points.label: Mediated service data exchange
points.text: Secure APIs must mediate data exchange between services.

sections.headline: Rule/policy-level requirements governing data access and processing constraints.

points.label: Least privilege access
points.text: Data access policies must enforce least-privilege constraints.

points.label: Compliance-aligned processing rules
points.text: Processing rules must align with regulatory compliance policies.

points.label: Cross-boundary flow constraints
points.text: Formal constraints must govern cross-boundary data flows.

sections.headline: Detection/monitoring requirements for anomalous access, integrity deviations, and forensics.

points.label: Detect anomalous data access
points.text: Monitoring mechanisms must detect anomalous data access.

points.label: Detect unauthorized computation changes
points.text: Integrity checks must detect unauthorized computation changes.

points.label: Forensic logging
points.text: Logging mechanisms must support forensic investigation.

sections.headline: Ensuring trustworthiness and correctness of computation nodes in distributed systems is difficult.

points.label: Opaque execution on dynamic infrastructure
points.text: Compute nodes may be dynamically provisioned from shared infrastructure; the client cannot directly verify faithful execution.
points.example: In a cloud-based distributed analytics system, compute nodes are provisioned on-demand; the client cannot verify whether each node executed the assigned computation correctly.

sections.headline: From the user perspective, data integrity and confidentiality may be at risk when computation/storage is outsourced.

points.label: Integrity risk
points.text: Users may receive incorrect outputs if integrity is not ensured end-to-end.

points.label: Confidentiality risk
points.text: Users may lose assurance that personal/sensitive data remains confidential in outsourced environments.

sections.headline: Integrity of distributed computation is not guaranteed because execution occurs in an untrusted environment.

points.label: Malicious node result manipulation
points.text: A computation node intentionally alters intermediate or final outputs returned to the coordinator/aggregator.
points.example: A compromised cloud VM modifies partial results before they are returned to the coordinator.

points.label: Compromised execution environment
points.text: OS/runtime compromise enables silent tampering with computations and intermediate data.
points.example: An attacker gains root access to a cloud VM participating in distributed processing and modifies intermediate dataset values before they are returned to the coordinator.

points.label: Data shuffle/inter-node tampering without integrity protection
points.text: Data exchanged between workers (shuffle/transfer) can be modified when integrity protection is missing or disabled.
points.example: In a misconfigured cluster without data integrity verification, an attacker intercepts shuffle traffic and injects altered partition data.

points.label: Byzantine worker behavior
points.text: A worker behaves arbitrarily/maliciously while outputs remain plausible, corrupting global computation.
points.example: In distributed machine learning, a node sends crafted gradient updates that subtly bias the model outcome toward adversarial objectives.

points.label: Remote data storage loss of control
points.text: Outsourcing storage reduces direct control over remotely stored data and its integrity/state.

sections.headline: Protocol-level solutions for cloud data storage integrity [1]

points.label: Remote data integrity verification protocol (Kumar & Subramanian, 2011)
points.text: Based on Elliptic Curve Cryptography and Sobol sequence; periodically verifies integrity of data stored at the CSP without retrieving the original data and generates probabilistic proofs of integrity.

sections.headline: Protecting VM memory pages in transit during migration [2]

points.label: Core idea
points.text: During live migration the entire VM memory is transferred as plaintext — exposing sensitive data to anyone on the network. The paper wraps the migration channel in an encrypted tunnel to protect data in transit.

refs.title: [1] An Efficient and Secure Protocol for Ensuring Data Storage Security in Cloud Computing
[2] A Framework for Secure Live Migration of Virtual Machines — Anala, Jyoti, Shobha — IEEE ICACCI 2013

sections.headline: Secure Storage and Computation Auditing Scheme [1]

points.label: TPA spot-check
points.text: Third-party auditor randomly samples ~15-33 tasks to detect cloud cheating on storage and computation

points.label: Result commitment
points.text: Merkle tree locks all results before TPA reveals which tasks it will sample
points.example: Cloud can't retroactively fix a bad result after seeing the challenge

points.label: Privacy discouragement
points.text: Designated verifier signature makes stolen data unprovable to buyers
points.example: Stolen medical records can't be sold authenticity can't be verified without private key

refs.title: [1] Security and privacy for storage and computation in cloud computing

sections.headline: Provider Security Capability Matching for Deployment [1]

points.label: The problem this solves
points.text: When choosing where to deploy a secure application, the developer has no structured way to know which cloud providers actually satisfy the security requirements. Provider documentation is unstructured, inconsistent, and not machine-readable.
points.example: Developer asks: does AWS support IS-07 data integrity control? — answer is buried in a 200-page PDF

points.label: The solution: structured provider security profiles
points.text: Each cloud provider gets a formal CAMEL model that lists exactly which security controls it supports. These profiles are populated automatically from CSA CAIQ questionnaire answers — the industry standard security self-assessment for cloud providers — by checking which controls received positive responses above a defined threshold
points.example: AWS CAIQ answers are parsed — for each security control, if enough questions are answered positively, that control is added to the AWS provider security profile

points.label: Deployment plan generated only from matching providers
points.text: The deployment planner compares the application's security requirements against all provider profiles and generates a deployment plan using only providers that satisfy every required control — automatically, without human comparison
points.example: Application needs confidentiality + data isolation — planner generates a deployment plan using only the 2 providers out of 10 whose profiles declare both capabilities

refs.title: [1] An Integrated Meta-model for Cloud Application Security Modelling — Kritikos & Massonet, ScienceDirect 2016

sections.headline: Security-Aware Reconfiguration Rules via SRL Extension [1]

points.label: Security rules that watch and react automatically
points.text: The paper extends the CAMEL Scalability Rule Language (SRL) to support security-oriented rules. When a security SLO is violated at runtime, for example a measured metric drops below its threshold, a reconfiguration rule fires automatically and moves the application to a more capable provider
points.example: Security rule: IF incident handling rate < 95% THEN migrate application to provider B which has a higher security capability score

points.label: Security controls as hard deployment filters
points.text: Before deployment even starts, required security controls act as hard constraints — any cloud provider that does not declare support for the required controls is automatically excluded from the candidate list
points.example: Application requires 'data encryption at rest' — the system eliminates every provider that did not declare this capability, without the developer doing anything manually

refs.title: [1] An Integrated Meta-model for Cloud Application Security Modelling — Kritikos & Massonet, ScienceDirect 2016

sections.headline: REST API Security Properties Must Be Enforced at the Application Layer [1]

points.label: Use-After-Free
points.text: A deleted resource must no longer be accessible via any API operation. The application must enforce resource lifecycle consistency. Any DELETE operation must invalidate all subsequent GET/PUT/PATCH on the same resource path

points.label: Resource-Leak Prevention
points.text: A failed resource creation must leave no side-effects in backend state. The application must guarantee atomicity of creation operations. Failed POST/PUT must not register the resource name, quota, or any metadata in backend state

points.label: Resource-Hierarchy Isolation
points.text: A child resource must only be accessible through its legitimate parent. Cross-parent access must be rejected at the application logic level. Resource path /parentA/children/child1 must not be accessible via /parentB/children/child1

points.label: User-Namespace Isolation
points.text: Resources created under one user token must not be accessible by another user token. Tenant isolation must be enforced at the API layer. Every resource access must validate that the requesting token matches the namespace of the resource owner

refs.title: [1] Security and privacy for storage and computation in cloud computing

points.label: Stateful fuzzing + active checkers
points.text: Extends REST API fuzzer with 4 rule checkers that actively generate tests to detect security violations beyond crash detection
points.example: Detects deleted resource still accessible (use-after-free), or user A accessing user B's resources (namespace violation)

refs.title: [1] Checking Security Properties of Cloud Services REST APIs

sections.headline: Blocking unauthorized traffic during live migration [1]

points.label: Core idea
points.text: Live migration exposes inter-VM and host-to-host traffic that standard firewalls cannot see. The paper adds per-VM firewall rules to block this hidden traffic and prevent migration to untrusted hosts.

refs.title: [1] A Framework for Secure Live Migration of Virtual Machines — Anala, Jyoti, Shobha — IEEE ICACCI 2013

sections.headline: Auto-blocking attacks targeting the migration process [1]

points.label: Core idea
points.text: Live migration is a critical window where the VM is vulnerable to network attacks. The paper uses an IDS that monitors traffic and automatically blocks suspicious sources before they can disrupt the migration.

refs.title: [1] A Framework for Secure Live Migration of Virtual Machines — Anala, Jyoti, Shobha — IEEE ICACCI 2013

sections.headline: Restricting who can trigger a live migration [1]

points.label: Core idea
points.text: Live migration has no built-in access control, anyone with admin rights can move any VM anywhere. The paper introduces RBAC to restrict migration privileges to authorized roles only.

refs.title: [1] A Framework for Secure Live Migration of Virtual Machines

Software|Solution|SAM.title: SAM-level Solution — Security Requirements Modeling for Cloud Applications

sections.headline: Security DSL for Application-Level Requirement Specification [1]

points.label: The solution: a formal security language built into the app model
points.text: The paper introduces a Domain-Specific Language (DSL) that lets developers express security requirements directly inside the application model at two levels: (1) high-level controls like 'enforce access control' and (2) measurable SLOs like 'incidents must be resolved within 1 hour in 95% of cases'
points.example: Instead of a Word document, the developer writes a formal security block in the app model, the deployment engine reads it directly and acts on it

points.label: OCL constraints catch mistakes before deployment
points.text: OCL (Object Constraint Language) rules are added on top of the DSL to automatically validate that the security model makes sense, if a requirement references a metric that does not exist, the system rejects the model immediately at design time, before any cloud resource is touched
points.example: Developer accidentally links a security SLO to a non-existent metric, OCL catches it instantly, deployment never starts

refs.title: [1] An Integrated Meta-model for Cloud Application Security Modelling — Kritikos & Massonet, ScienceDirect 2016
